Term.definition: A matrix whose inverse is equal to its conjugate transpose.
A matrix with nonzero entries only on its main diagonal.
Selecting specific elements or subarrays from an array using start:stop:step notation.
A tuple representing the dimensions of a NumPy array.
Selecting specific portions of a sequence, such as a list or array, using a defined range of indices.
Data type of elements stored in a NumPy array, such as float32 or int64.
A mapping from data values to colors, used to visualize data in plots or images.
A popular Python library for creating static, animated, and interactive visualizations.
An argument in matplotlib specifying which colormap to use for displaying image data.
A Python library for numerical computing, especially for working with arrays and matrices.
A single numerical value, not an array or collection.
Automatic expansion of arrays with different shapes for elementwise operations in NumPy.
Operation applied independently to each element of an array.
Selecting array elements using a boolean array as a mask.
An exception raised in Python when a function receives an argument of the right type but inappropriate value.
A dimension along which operations are performed in NumPy arrays, e.g., rows (axis 0) or columns (axis 1).
A square matrix where all elements outside the main diagonal are zero.
Non-negative values from the singular value decomposition (SVD) representing the magnitude of each component.
Singular Value Decomposition, a matrix factorization technique in linear algebra.
A NumPy function that changes the shape of an array without changing its data.
Transforming operations to work on entire arrays instead of element by element, improving performance.
Specifies the dimension along which an operation is performed in a multi-dimensional array.
A new array object that looks at the same data as the original array, without copying it.
Selecting a subset of elements from an array or sequence using start:stop:step notation.
This statement imports the Pandas library in Python and assigns it the alias 'pd' for better readability and code convention.
A matrix whose rows and columns are perpendicular unit vectors; its inverse equals its transpose.
A matrix where all non-diagonal elements are zero; only main diagonal may have nonzero values.
A temporary value used to reserve space until actual data is assigned.
A function argument specified by name, not just position, improving code clarity.
The dimensions of an array, usually expressed as a tuple of integers.
A Python library for efficient numerical computations, especially with arrays and matrices.
A type of machine learning task predicting continuous values based on input data.
An ordered one-dimensional array of numbers, often used in mathematical computations.
Change the shape of an array without changing its data.
Return evenly spaced values within a given interval as a NumPy array.
Tuple indicating the dimensions of an array.
Attribute that returns the transpose of an array in NumPy.
Transforming a multi-dimensional array into a one-dimensional array.
The first row in a CSV file, typically containing column names.
NumPy function that returns the index of the maximum value in an array.
A function describing the relative likelihood for a random variable to take on a given value.
A NumPy data type for arbitrary Python objects, allowing arrays to store any object type.
A NumPy scalar type representing fixed-size byte strings, used for storing text data in arrays.
A NumPy scalar type for fixed-size Unicode strings, supporting international text in arrays.
A program or algorithm used to encode or decode data, especially for text encoding formats.
The accuracy with which real numbers are represented in a computer using floating-point format.
A module nested within another module, providing additional functionality or organization.
A special attribute of an object, accessed like a variable but often computed dynamically.
An immutable, ordered collection of elements, often used to group related data.
A component of an image representing intensity for a specific color, like red, green, or blue.
Axes are the dimensions along which data is organized in an array or matrix.
A view is a new array object that looks at the same data as the original array.
To permute means to rearrange the order of elements or axes in an array.
An immutable sequence type in Python, similar to a list but cannot be changed after creation.
An attribute in NumPy arrays indicating the data type of the array's elements.
Describes arrays that can be automatically expanded to have compatible shapes for elementwise operations.
Change the shape of an array without changing its data.
Insert a new axis into an array, increasing its dimensionality.
Converts a multi-dimensional array into a one-dimensional array.
Changes the shape of an array without changing its data.
Change the shape of an array without changing its data.
Return evenly spaced values within a given interval as a NumPy array.
An operation that modifies data directly, without creating a new copy of the data.
Positions or addresses of elements within an array or list.
A dimension along which operations like sorting or summing are performed in multi-dimensional arrays.
Displays the current figure or plot in a graphical window.
Describes matrices whose columns and rows are perpendicular unit vectors; their inverse equals their transpose.
Selecting a subset of elements from sequences like lists, arrays, or matrices using index ranges.
Automatic expansion of array shapes to make operations possible in NumPy or similar libraries.
A single numerical value, as opposed to an array or matrix.
A function that determines the output of a neural network node.
A character encoding standard that supports most of the worldâ€™s writing systems.
A data structure that defines how to convert or replace characters in a string.
Predefined variables in the string module, like string.digits or string.punctuation.
NumPy method to change the shape of an array without changing its data.
NumPy function that returns evenly spaced values within a given interval.
A matrix factorization technique used in linear algebra for dimensionality reduction and data compression.
Pandas is a Python package designed for easy and intuitive manipulation of 'relational' or 'labeled' data.
NumPy is a fast and powerful library for basic operations with data in Python.
A matrix whose rows and columns are perpendicular unit vectors; its transpose is also its inverse.
A numeric representation for real numbers, allowing fractional values and a wide range of magnitudes.
A function that constrains values in an array to a specified minimum and maximum range.
A character or string that separates fields or values in a text file.
Parameter specifying the number of lines to skip at the start of a file when reading data.
Parameter in numpy functions to skip a specified number of lines at the file's start.
A parameter specifying the format for saving data, such as decimal or exponential notation.
Arrays are broadcastable if they can be automatically expanded to have compatible shapes for operations.
Converts a multi-dimensional array into a one-dimensional array copy.
Describes arrays that can be automatically expanded to have compatible shapes for operations.
N-dimensional arrays provided by NumPy to store and manipulate data efficiently.
A data structure that stores elements of the same type in a fixed-size sequence.
Mathematical functions that describe the probability of different outcomes in a random experiment.
Functions that describe how probabilities are distributed over possible values.
A probability distribution where all outcomes in a finite set are equally likely.
A measure of how much values in a dataset differ from the mean.
Special block in Python that runs code only when the script is executed directly, not when imported.
A file containing Python code intended to be executed as a program.
NumPy method to change the shape of an array without changing its data.
NumPy function that returns evenly spaced values within a given interval.
Common alias for the NumPy library, used for numerical operations in Python.
A matrix containing singular values from Singular Value Decomposition (SVD).
A matrix containing right singular vectors from Singular Value Decomposition (SVD).
A Matplotlib function to display an image from a NumPy array.
In Python, '...' used for advanced slicing in multidimensional arrays.
Applying an operation independently to each element in an array or collection.
An array whose elements are either True or False values.
Automatic expansion of arrays of different shapes during arithmetic operations in NumPy.
Singular Value Decomposition; a matrix factorization technique used in linear algebra.
Dimensions along which operations like summing or transposing are performed in arrays.
To rearrange the order of axes or elements in an array.
Operation that swaps or reorders the axes of an array or matrix.
Automatic expansion of arrays with different shapes to perform element-wise operations.
An error detected during execution that interrupts the normal flow of a program.
An immutable ordered collection of elements, often used to group related data in Python.
